reference.title: DITA OT error messages
reference.shortdesc: The error messages generated by the DITA Open Toolkit contain a message ID, severity information, and message text. This topic lists each error message generated by the toolkit and provides additional information that might be helpful in understanding and resolving the error condition.

section.p:
Each message ID is composed of a message prefix, a message number, and a letter that indicates the severity (I, E, or F). The toolkit uses the following severity scale:
Informational (I) The toolkit encountered a condition of which you should be aware. For example, draft comments and required-up content are enabled and will be rendered in the output.
Warning (W) The toolkit encountered a problem that should be corrected. Processing will contine, but the output might not be as expected.
Error (E) The toolkit encountered a more severve problem, and the output is affected. For example, some content is missing or invalid; the content is not rendered in the output
Fatal (F) The toolkit encountered a severe condition, processing stopped, and no output is generated.

sthead.stentry: Individual cells in this table may be used to push additional explanations for any existing error message into the generated message topic.

strow.stentry:
To add additional explanation to any message, add the explanation to this table in a single sell, and set the the following attributes on the <stentry> tag:
conref="DITA-messages.xml#msgs/MESSAGEID-extra" -- for example, use the following to add additional info to message DOTX001F: conref="DITA-messages.xml#msgs/DOTX001F-extra"
conaction="pushreplace"

The default transformation types that ship with the toolkit include xhtml, eclipsehelp, pdf (or pdf2), tocjs, htmlhelp, javahelp, odt, eclipsecontent, troff, docbook, and wordrtf. Additional transformation types might be available, if additional toolkit plug-ins are installed.

The input parameter was not specified, so there is no DITA or DITAMAP file to transform. Ensure the parameter is set properly; see DITA-OT Ant arguments or DITA-OT Command line tool arguments if you are unsure how to specify the input file.
Ensure that the input file path and file name are specified correctly.
An alternate stylesheet was specified to run in place of the default XSLT, but the stylesheet could not be loaded. Ensure that the stylesheet file path and file name are specified correctly.
This optional parameter is used to set the extension for DITA topics in the temporary processing directory. Only "dita", ".dita", "xml", or ".xml" are allowed.
These parameters are deprecated; use the args.input parameter instead.

If the CSSPATH parameter specifies an absolute path, it must be system independent, such as http://www.example.org/. Absolute paths on the local file system are broken when the content is moved to a new system.

The running footer file, which contains content to be added to the bottom of each XHTML output topic, cannot be located or read. This usually is caused by a typo in the parameter value. Also ensure that the value is not specified with "file:" as a prefix.

The running header file, which contains content to be added to the top of each XHTML output topic, cannot be located or read. This usually is caused by a typo in the parameter value. Also ensure that the value is not specified with "file:" as a prefix.

The running heading file, which contains content to be added to the <head> section of each XHTML output topic, cannot be located or read. This usually is caused by a typo in the parameter value. Also ensure that the value is not specified with "file:" as a prefix.

By default, the DITA-OT expects to find Apache FOP in the fop/ directory inside of the PDF plug-in. If you are using an alternate renderer, or if you have placed FOP in a different directory, you need to update your configuration accordingly.
An alternate stylesheet was specified to run in place of the default XSL-FO output process, but that stylesheet could not be loaded. Correct the parameter to specify a valid stylesheet.
This condition is ignored, as imandared in the OASIS DITA specification.
This condition is ignored, as imandared in the OASIS DITA specification.
See for a list of available parameters and values.
See for a list of available parameters and values.
See for a list of available parameters and values.

The transformation could not create a temporary directory; this usually is caused by account control settings that prevent creating a temporary directory in the specified location. Verify that you have permission to write to the default location, or specify an alternate temporary-directory location. See DITA-OT Ant arguments or DITA-OT Command line tool arguments for details on how to specify the temporary directory.

This message occurs when an Ant build calls a DITA-OT pipeline module directly instead of using the default call to the module. Ensure that all parameters are set correctly in your Ant build. The syntax for extparam is "name1=value1;name2=value2".
If a condition is defined more than once (such as setting audience="all" to be included, then resetting it to be excluded), only the first definition is used.
The transformation could not create files properly during the transformation; the results might not be as expected.

This message might indicate an invalid input file (for example, a PDF file rather than a DITA map), an input file that uses invalid elements, or a DITA file that has errors and cannot be parsed as XML. You also might be using a specialized DITA document type that needs external plug-ins in order to be parsed correctly. The message issued by the XML parser should provide additional information.

his message might indicate an invalid input file (for example, a PDF file rather than a DITA map), an input file that uses invalid elements, or a DITA file that has errors and cannot be parsed as XML. You also might be using a specialized DITA document type that needs external plug-ins in order to be parsed correctly. The message issued by the XML parser should provide additional information.
An empty <indexterm> element was found; it will appear in the index as ***. Remove the index term entry from the source.
The transformation failed because the input file was not specified; log file names are based on the name of the input file, so no log could be generated.
This will appear when one installed plug-in requires another in order to function correctly, but the required plug-in is not found. The installed plug-in is ignored.

This might appear if filter conditions on the root element of a topic cause the entire topic to be filtered out. To remove this message, place filter conditions on the map element that references the topic; this will prevent the build from accessing this file.
Your build is excluding all content. Change either the input file or the .ditaval file.
Verify that the image either exists in the source location or already is presennt in the output directory.

This message appears in the following cases:
Errors earlier in the transformation prevented the topic merge from running; correct any errors and try the build again.
An Ant build or plug-in is directly and improperly calling the topic merge module. Fix the Ant build or plug-in.

This message is displayed if an Ant build or plug-in is directly calling the topic merge module, or if earlier errors resulted in problems with some of the content. If the topic merge module is called correctly, then this indicates a program error that should be reported to the DITA-OT development team at .

When referencing a non-DITA file, the @format attribute must indicate the type of file referenced, for example, "html" or "pdf". Otherwise, the transformation attempts to parse the referenced document as a DITA topic.
The @domains attribute is used in specialized DITA documents to help determine which domain elements are legal. This message only appears if DITA specialization is not defined properly.
All specialized DITA elements must define a @class attribute to provide ancestry information. This message appears when a specialized DITA element does not define a @class attribute.
This informational message is intended to help you catch filter conditions that might have been specified improperly; if the value is correct, no action is needed.
DITA processing is based on @class attributes. Usually these are defaulted in the DTD or Schema; if no DTD or Schema is used, the @class attributes must be explicitly included in the map or topic.

This message appears when a topic is outside the scope of the map, for example, if the input map references "../other-directory/some.dita". The result causes an output file to be created outside of the output directory. See DITA-OT Ant arguments (outer.control and generate.copy.outer) or DITA-OT command-line tool arguments (/outercontrol and /generateouter) for more details.

This message appears when a topic is outside the scope of the map, for example, if the input map references "../other-directory/some.dita". The result causes an output file to be created outside of the output directory. See DITA-OT Ant arguments (outer.control and generate.copy.outer) or DITA-OT command-line tool arguments (/outercontrol and /generateouter) for more details.
DITA processing is based on @class attributes. Usually these are defaulted in the DTD or Schema; if no DTD or Schema is used, the @class attributes must be explicitly included in the map or topic.
This indicated an error in creating specialized metadata elements. Verify that the document type that you are using is complete and complies with DITA specialization rules.
See the topic on Conref Push in the DITA specification for syntax information.
See the topic on Conref Push in the DITA specification for syntax information.
The value of the @conref attribute must be a URI reference to a DITA element. See the topic on URI-based addressing in the DITA specification for syntax information.

The conref push function was used to replace a single element with two or more alternatives. Only one element can directly replace another using conref push. See Conref Push in the DITA specification for more information about the conref-push "replace" function.

The target for a conref push action does not exist; ensure that the syntax is correct and that the target exists. See the topic on URI-based addressing in the DITA specification. If the syntax is correct, the target might have filtered out of your build using a .ditaval file.
See the topic on Conref Push in the DITA specification for syntax information.
No response is needed if the keys are defined as expected; this is an informational message, intended to help catch incorrectly-defined keys.
See the conkeyref definition for syntax information.
This message is intended to help you locate incorrectly-specified keys; if the key was specified correctly, ignore this message.
A DITA subject scheme map was used to limit the values that are available to the specified attribute. Correct the attribute so that it uses one of the permitted values.

The Eclipse index will contain a value such as "See also otherEntry", but otherEntry does not exist. The index reference will be broken unless this plug-in is always loaded into Eclipse with another plug-in that defines otherEntry as an index term.

The target for a coderef element, which specifies an external text-based file, could not be located or loaded. Verify that the reference is correct.
Note that for security reasons, references to code samples outside of the scope of the map directory are not supported by default, as this could allow a reference to access and display any restricted or hidden file on the system. If you are certain that the path is valid and the file should be loaded, a workaround is to set a parameter to allow these references. See DITA-OT Ant arguments (outer.control and generate.copy.outer) or DITA-OT command-line tool arguments (/outercontrol and /generateouter) for details.
The DITA-OT supports a special syntax on coderef elements to specify the character set of the target document. See for more information.

By default, the DITA-OT supports the extensions "dita" and "xml" for DITA topics, as mandated by the DITA specification. Verify that your topics use one of these extensions, or configure the toolkit to allow additional extensions.

This build uses generated text, such as the phrase "Related information" that is generated before link groups. The toolkit was unable to locate the string %1 for your specified language, so the string appears in the default language. This generally indicates that the toolkit strings needs to be updated to support your language, or that your language setting is incorrect.
The Eclipse help system requires a title in the project files that are generated from your map. Add a title to your input map.

Eclipse uses anchor references to connect with other TOC files. For this to work in content generated from a DITA map, the anchorref element must reference either an existing Eclipse TOC XML file or another DITA map.
Eclipse builds use DITA's <navref> element to pull in other Eclipse TOC files. The build found a <navref> element that does not reference any other file; the element is ignored.
To remove this message, provide a navigation title for the referenced object in the map or topic, or ensure that you are referencing a valid local DITA target.

Set the @format attribute to identify the file format. If the reference is to a DITA document, ensure that the document uses a valid DITA extension; by default, the supported extensions are "dita" and "xml".
The HTML Help compileronly can include certain types of information in the .CHM file; the current reference is not included.
To fix the table of contents, specify a navigation title in your map or ensure that the referenced file is local and can be accessed.
Ensure that the file exists and can be read.
No title was found in the specified topic, so the table of contents will use the indicated fallback value for this topic.

The conref attribute must be a URI reference to an existing DITA element. See the topic on URI-based addressing in the DITA specification. Note that the name of the file in this message might have been changed to use '.dita' or '.xml' instead of the original extension used by the file; it also might include a path to the temporary directory rather than to the original.
If the target element exists in your source file, check to make sure it is not filtered out of the build with a .ditaval file (which will remove the target before conref processing runs).
When pulling content with a @conref attribute, you can only pull from a single element, but the target ID appears twice in the referenced topic.
This message is deprecated and should no longer be displayed.
The @conref attribute must be a URI reference to a DITA element. See the topic on URI-based addressing in the DITA specification for more information.
The @conref attribute must be a URI reference to a DITA element. See the topic on URI-based addressing in the DITA specification for more information.

This warning is intended to catch instances where a non-DITA format setting unexpectedly cascades to a DITA topic, which prevents the topic from being processed. To remove this message, set the @format attribute directly on the indicated reference.

Found a value such as <xref href="">link text</xref>. The empty @href attribute does not serve a purpose and has caused problems with tools in the past; remove the attribute entirely or specify a value.

The @type attribute is intended to describe the type of the target; for example, a reference to a concept topic might use type="concept". This attribute generally is optional, as the DITA-OT build automatically determines the value during processing. In this case, the @type attribute lists a more general type than what is actually found. This might result in unexpected sorting for links to this topic.

The @type attribute is intended to describe the type of the target; for example, a reference to a concept topic might use type="concept". This attribute generally is optional, as the DITA-OT build automatically determines the value during processing. In this case, the specified type value does not match the target, which might cause your links to sort inappropriately.
The DITA-OT can dynamically retrieve titles only when the target is a local (not peer or external) DITA resource.
The DITA-OT can dynamically retrieve titles only when the target is a local DITA resource.
The build was unable to get a title from the referenced topic; a navigation title was created based on the specified <linktext> element inside of <topicmeta>.

If the target is a local DITA topic, ensure the reference is correct and the topic is available. Otherwise, provide a navigation title, and ensure the @scope and @format attributes are set appropriately.
The DITA-OT can dynamically retrieve titles and link text only when the target is a local (not peer or external) DITA resource.
The DITA-OT can dynamically retrieve titles only when the target is a local DITA resource.
The reference to this document did not specify any link text for generated map-based links; the navigation title is used as fallback.
The referenced file did not specify any link text for generated map-based links, and no fallback text was located. Any links generated from this reference will have incorrect link text.
The link or cross reference has no target specified and will not generate a link.

The @type attribute in DITA is intended to describe the type of the target; for example, a reference to a concept topic may use type="concept". This attribute generally is optional, as the DITA-OT build automatically determines the value during processing. In this case, the type attribute lists a more general type than what is actually found. This might result in unexpected sorting for links to this topic.

The @type attribute in DITA is intended to describe the type of the target; for example, a reference to a concept topic may use type="concept". This attribute generally is optional, as the DITA-OT build automatically determines the value during processing. In this case, the specified type value does not match the target, which might cause your links to be sorted inappropriately.

The build attempted to access the specified file in order to retrive a title or short description, but the file could not be found. If the file exists, a DITAVAL file might have been used to exclude the file contents from the build. Be aware that the above path information might not match the link in your topic.

When a link or cross reference does not have content, the build attempts to use the target title as link text. If the target is unavailable, be sure to set the @scope attribute to an appropriate value. If the target does not have a title (such as when linking to a paragraph), be sure to provide link text inside the cross reference.

An <xref> element specifies type="li", which indicates a link to a list item, but the item number could not be determined to use as link text. Specify link text inside the reference, or ensure that you are referencing an available list item.

The cross reference goes to a list item in an unordered list. The process could not automatically generate link text because the list item is not numbered. Provide link text within the cross reference.

An <xref> element specifies type="fn", which indicates a link to a footnote, but the footnote number could not be determined to use as link text. Specify link text inside the reference, or ensure that you are referencing an available footnote.

An <xref> element specifies type="dlentry", which indicates a link to a definition list entry, but the term could not be located to use as link text. Specify link text inside the reference, or ensure that you are referencing an available definition list entry
No title was found for the current document, so the XHTML output file will set the <title> to "***". This value generally is displayed in the title bar at the top of a browser.

The <object> element in XHTML does not support using longdescref for accessibility. To make the object accessible, you might need to add text before or after the element. You might also be able to handle it with a <param> element inside the object.

This message is generated when the output contains required cleanup; it enables you to locate which topics contain content that needs to be cleaned up. These items appear in your output with styling that makes them stand out, and the items are hidden when the draft parameter is not issued.

This message is generated when the output contains draft comments; it enables you to locate which topics contain draft comments. Each draft comment is displayed in your XHTML output; the comments are hidden when the draft parameter is not issued.

Because of the way XML and DITA are defined, it generally is not possible to prohibit adding a second title to a section during editing (or to force that title to come first). However, the DITA specification states that only one title should be used in a section. When multiple titles are found, only the first one will appear in the output.

If it is important to flag this piece of information, place a flag on the block element that contains your phrase. If you just want to have an image next to the phrase, place an image directly into the document.

In most cases, the DITA-OT removes duplicate links. However, if two links to the same resource use different attributes or link text, it is possible for them to appear together. For example, if the same link shows up with role="next" and again with no specified role, it might show up as both the "Next topic" link and as a related link. Note that links generated from a <reltable> in a DITA map have the role attribute set to "friend".
The <area> element in an image map must provide a link target for the specified area. Add an <xref> element as a child of <area> and ensure that it specifies a link target.

Cross reference text inside the <area> element is used to provide accessibility for screen readers that can identify different areas of an image map. If text cannot be retrieved automatically by referencing a DITA element, it should be specified directly in the cross reference.
The specified value was passed through as-is to the area element in the XHTML.
The area element is intended to define a region in an image map; coordinates must be specified in order to define that region.

The build will not look for peer or external topics before compiling your CHM file, so they might not be included. If you are referencing an actual HTML file that will not be available, it cannot be included in the project, and you should set the @toc attribute on the topicref element to "no". Otherwise, check to be sure your HTML file was included in the CHM; if it was not, place it in the correct location with your other output files and recompile.
The PDF, ODT, and RTF output processes cannot automatically convert non-DITA content into DITA in order to merge it with the rest of your content. The referenced items are ignored.
Eclipse requires that an ID be specified when creating an Eclipse Help project; the toolkit expects to locate that ID on the root element of your input map.

The toolkit is attempting to add generated text, such as the string "Related information" that appears above links. The requested string could not be found in any language. Your output might contain a meaningful string, or it might contain a code that was intended to map to a string. This usually indicates an error in a plug-in or XSL override; either the string was requested incorrectly, or you need to provide a mapping for the string in all of the languages that you require.

This message occurs if a map references another map, and then that second map (or another further nested map) references the original map. The result is an infinite nesting of maps; correct the chain of map references in order to remove the circular reference.
This message occurs when a DITAVAL file contains multiple styling rules that apply to the same element.

The "flagit" named template was deprecated in DITA-OT, version 1.4, when the OASIS standard formalized the DITAVAL syntax. The template is removed in DITA-OT 1.6. Update any stylesheets that use this template.

The build attempted to access the specified file in order to retrive a title or short description, but the file could not be found. If the file exists, a DITAVAL file might have been used to exclude the file contents. Another possibility is that the file is located outside of the scope of the main input directory, and so it was not available because the onlytopic.in.map or /onlytopicinmap parameter was specified. Be aware that the above path information might not match the link in your topic.
The link uses valid syntax to reference a DITA element, but that element cannot be found. Verify that the element exists and that itis not removed from the build by DITAVAL-based filtering.

Processing for terms, acronyms, or abbreviated forms associate the key from the element @keyref attribute with a glossentry (glossary entry) topic. This message appears if the key was defined but was not associated with a glossentry topic. The process will try to use the best available fallback, usually the title of the referenced topic.

Processing for abbreviated form elements will associate the key from the element keyref attribute with a glossentry (glossary entry) topic. This message appears if the key was defined but was not associated with a glossentry topic. This element only is supported with keys that are associated with glossary topics; the element will not generate any output. Correct the reference, or use a different element to reference your topic.

According to the DITA specification, map references only can point to DITA maps, DITA topics, or non-DITA resource. You can reference elements within a topic only from cross references (using <xref> or similar) inside of a topic. See the @href attribute description in the DITA specification topic concerning the topicref element.

This message appears when generating PDF or ODT output that includes a link to a local topic, but the referenced topic is not part of the map itself. This results in a broken link. Include the topic in your map or remove the link from the build.
The @copy-to attribute is used to copy a topic over a document that already exists. Ensure that any @copy-to attributes use a unique name so that the copy will not overwrite existing content.

Two different topics are copied to the same location using copy-to; as a result, one of these files would be over-written. Only the first instance of this copy-to value is recognized. Correct the use of copy-to attributes.

This message indicates that your custom XSLT or plug-ins rely on templates that will be removed in an upcoming release. Typically this occurs when a named template has been converted to a mode template; update any code that uses the deprecated template.

This PDF build uses generated text, such as the phrase "Related information" (which is generated above many link groups). The toolkit could not locate the string %1 for your specified language, so the string will appear in the default language. Either the toolkit strings need to be updated to support your language, or that your language setting is incorrect.
